Award.AwardTitle: MRI - Development of Real Time Simulator for Smart Grid Systems Integrated with Distributed Renewable Energy Sources

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to design and develop a real time simulator integrated with distributed renewable energy sources, storage options, self-healing capabilities, cyber security with power distribution and communication networks for investigating the smart grid technologies with actual hardware in the loop. The approach is to develop a test bed which will provide a unique opportunity to validate the understanding and operation of very complex smart grid systems embedded with cyber security.
Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of the proposed activity is found in the interdisciplinary approach to the development of an innovative design methodology for development real time simulator with distributed renewable energy sources and interface to the utility at very high power levels. The proposed research is of transformative nature due to the integration of real time digital simulation with the hardware in the loop for validation of cyber security for smart grid systems.

Broader Impacts: This project will have a significant impact on the meeting of the Department of Energy goals of 20% wind energy by 2030. The broader impacts are the (i) workforce development and research training of future engineers/scientists for the design, build and maintain future smart grid systems, (ii) development of modular courses for integration into existing courses at the undergraduate and graduate level, (iii) recruitment of students from underrepresented groups especially for collaborative project-based learning, implementation, and testing of smart renewable energy systems, (iv) dissemination of the knowledge through short courses, web-based tutorials, and journal publications, and (v) outreach activities to community college and high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The US Department of Energy envisions that wind power generation may constitute up to 20% and 35% of the total electricity production by years 2030 and 2050 respectively. The challenges for integrating higher levels of variable renewable generation with smart grid have to be addressed. One of the major challenges is the frequency response of renewable energy generation. When a large wind generation source shuts down, the frequency of the electric power system drops because of the imbalance between generation and load. Because the primary and secondary inertial responses of renewable energy sources differ from the conventional synchronous generators, we need to investigate the frequency response at different penetration levels. The electric power industry is also facing new challenges with respect to deliberate cyber-attacks such as from disgruntled employees, industrial espionage, natural disasters and terrorists. In order to investigate the frequency response and cyber security of the smart grid, we have developed real time simulator.

The principal objective of this simulator is to design and develop a single, well-integrated instrument for investigating the reliability and cyber security of smart grid systems. The salient features of the simulator are (i) the integration of distributed renewable energy sources for hardware in the loop simulations and validations, (ii) plug and play capabilities for testing different types of energy storage systems, advanced control systems and smart appliances, and (iii) embedded cyber security for dynamic monitoring and detection of malicious attacks. The major hardware and software components, communication protocols and renewable energy sources were integrated into a single real time simulator for verification of reliability and cyber security of smart grid systems. Using the real time simulator, we conducted the research in the areas of dynamic modeling of power systems with renewable energy sources, wide area monitoring of power systems, cyber security and sustainability, and power electronic systems.

The real time simulator facility has been integrated to the research and training mission at Texas Tech University in areas related to renewable energy, power system reliability and cyber security. The availability of this shared facility, accelerated the collaborations amongst  the faculty and graduate students from the colleges of engineering, arts and sciences, business and law for investigating the various aspects of smart grid systems. The value added aspect of the graduate education and research traineeship to our students will be understanding, accommodation and verification of overall functionalities of smart grid technologies. The shared facilities were made available for training of graduate students in an interdisciplinary setting. A number of graduate students used these facilities in their thesis work under the supervision of various faculty members. These facilities were made available for under graduate students conducting senior capstone design projects. Tours of undergraduate and graduate students were organized to demonstrate the capabilities of the real time simulator. We have also used these facilities as a recruiting tool for graduate students.  Availability of these facilities enabled us to develop collaborations with major industries related to smart grid technologies.
